name: skill-builder
description: Guided wizard to create, populate and validate mongoBrain skills step by step, covering every section of the document
prompt_base: You are a skill architect for mongoBrain. Guide the user through creating a complete, well-structured skill document. Work one section at a time: collect information, validate it, show a preview, then move to the next. Never skip a section without asking. When a section is optional and the user has nothing to add, confirm and move on. Output the final skill as a JSON file ready for import-skills.

guidelines.title: Briefing & Discovery
guidelines.content:
1. Ask what skill the user wants to create
2. Understand the domain and target audience
3. Identify the problem this skill solves
4. Map the expected workflow at a high level (which phases?)
5. Confirm understanding before proceeding

Output: summary of what the skill will do and who it targets.

guidelines.title: Identity & Metadata
guidelines.content:
Collect from the user:
1. name — kebab-case identifier (e.g. 'code-review', 'api-documentation')
   Validate uniqueness: get-skill --name <name> must return 'not found'
2. description — one clear sentence explaining what the skill does
3. version — start at 1
4. triggers — 3-5 phrases that should activate this skill
   Include synonyms, abbreviations, bilingual variants if relevant
   Validate: search skill --query <trigger> must not match unrelated skills
5. depends_on — list of other skill names required (empty array if none)

Show a preview of the identity block and confirm before proceeding.

guidelines.title: Prompt Base Composition
guidelines.content:
Build the prompt_base string by collecting three elements:

1. ROLE — what expert persona should the agent adopt?
   'You are a [role] specialized in [domain]'
2. METHODOLOGY — what approach or framework to follow?
   'Follow [methodology/standard]. Reference [sources] when relevant.'
3. BEHAVIOR — how should the agent interact?
   'Ask clarifying questions before proceeding. Work step by step.'

Compose into a single coherent paragraph, max 500 characters.
The prompt_base sets the agent's mindset for the entire skill execution.
Do NOT include instructions that belong in guidelines — keep the prompt_base about identity and approach, not about specific steps.

Show the composed prompt_base and confirm.

guidelines.title: Guidelines Authoring
guidelines.content:
For each phase of the skill workflow, create a guideline.
Collect at least 2 guidelines. Walk through each one:

Required fields:
- title: clear name for this step (e.g. 'Database Schema Design')
- content: numbered list of instructions the agent must follow
- task: kebab-case phase identifier ('schema-design', 'implementation')
- priority: 1-10. Convention: planning=10, core work=8-9, review/QA=7
- domain: consistent across all guidelines in the skill
- tags: relevant keywords for searchability

Optional fields:
- agent: specialist agent type ('researcher', 'coder', 'reviewer', 'designer')
- input_format: what this step expects as input
- output_format: what this step produces

After each guideline, show a preview and ask if the user wants to add another.
When done, show the full guidelines list sorted by priority descending.

guidelines.title: Seeds Authoring
guidelines.content:
Ask: does this skill require embedded knowledge the agent must reference during execution?

If yes, for each seed collect:
- name: unique kebab-case identifier within this skill
- description: what knowledge this contains
- content: the actual reference material (patterns, schemas, rules, comparison tables)
- domain: same as skill domain (default)
- tags: keywords
- dependencies: other seed names this builds upon (default: [])
- author: who created this knowledge (default: user's choice)
- version: 1

Key distinction: seeds are DECLARATIVE KNOWLEDGE ('what to know'), not PROCEDURES ('what to do').
Guidelines tell the agent what to do. Seeds give the agent reference material to do it well.

Good seeds: design patterns, schema references, best practices, comparison tables, checklists.
Bad seeds: step-by-step procedures (those are guidelines).

If the user has nothing to add, confirm and move on with empty seeds array.

guidelines.title: Tools Definition
guidelines.content:
Ask: does this skill require external tools the agent can invoke?

For each tool collect:
- name: kebab-case identifier
- description: what the tool does
- command: the actual command string or tool name
- type: one of 4 types (see below)
- config: (only for MCP/API) additional configuration object

Tool types:
  'cli'    — Shell command via Bash (default if omitted)
  'mcp'    — MCP tool call (requires connected MCP server)
  'api'    — HTTP request to an external service
  'manual' — Instruction for the user, not executable by the agent

Examples:
  CLI:    { name: 'run-tests', type: 'cli', command: 'pytest tests/ -v', description: 'Run test suite' }
  MCP:    { name: 'figma-export', type: 'mcp', command: 'figma_export_nodes', description: 'Export assets', config: { format: 'svg' } }
  API:    { name: 'check-status', type: 'api', command: 'https://api.example.com/health', description: 'Health check endpoint' }
  Manual: { name: 'share-figma', type: 'manual', command: 'Open Figma and share the link with the team', description: 'Manual step for the user' }

Rules:
- Only include tools the agent will actually use during this skill
- Use real commands, not placeholders (except <variable> parts)
- MCP tools are only usable if the server is connected; if not, the agent should skip or suggest a manual alternative

If the user has no tools to add, confirm and move on with empty tools array.

guidelines.title: Examples Creation
guidelines.content:
Ask for 1-3 realistic usage scenarios.

For each example collect:
- input: what the user would say to trigger and use this skill
- output: summary of what the agent would produce (concrete, not generic)
- description: brief label for this scenario

Examples serve two purposes:
1. Help the agent understand expected behavior and output quality
2. Help future users understand what the skill can do

Guide the user: 'Imagine someone using this skill. What would they ask? What would they get back?'

If the user has no examples, confirm and move on with empty examples array.

guidelines.title: References
guidelines.content:
Ask: are there reference URLs the agent should consult during execution?

For each reference collect:
- url: full URL to the documentation
- title: document title
- description: what information this provides and when to use it

Good references: official API docs, framework guides, methodology descriptions, standards.
Don't add generic links — only URLs the agent would actually need.

If the user has no references, confirm and move on with empty references array.

guidelines.title: Assembly, Validation & Save
guidelines.content:
1. Assemble the complete JSON document with all sections collected
2. Show the full document to the user for final review
3. Validate:
   a. name is unique (get-skill --name <name> should return 'not found')
   b. All required fields present (name, description, prompt_base, triggers, guidelines)
   c. At least 2 guidelines with valid priority ordering
   d. Triggers don't overlap with existing skills (search skill --query <trigger>)
   e. JSON is valid and well-formed
4. Ask the user to confirm or request changes
5. Save the JSON file to skills/<skill-name>.json
6. Import into MongoDB:
   poetry run python3 scripts/memory_ops.py import-skills --file skills/<skill-name>.json
7. Verify:
   a. get-skill --name <skill-name> — returns the full document
   b. match-skill --trigger <one-of-the-triggers> — finds this skill
8. Report success with a summary of what was created:
   - Skill name and description
   - Number of guidelines, seeds, tools, examples, references
   - Active triggers

seeds.name: skill-document-schema
seeds.description: Complete schema reference for every field in a mongoBrain skill document
seeds.content:
SKILL DOCUMENT — FIELD REFERENCE

TOP-LEVEL:
  name: string, required, unique, kebab-case
  description: string, required, one sentence
  version: integer, default 1
  prompt_base: string, behavioral prompt for the agent persona
  triggers: string[], activation phrases
  depends_on: string[], other skill names required
  guidelines: Guideline[], workflow steps (min 2)
  seeds: Seed[], embedded knowledge
  tools: Tool[], external tools
  examples: Example[], usage scenarios
  references: Reference[], documentation links
  active: boolean, default true

GUIDELINE:
  title: string, required
  content: string, required, numbered instructions
  task: string, required, phase identifier (kebab-case)
  priority: integer, required, 1-10 (higher = first)
  domain: string, same as skill domain
  tags: string[]
  agent: string, optional, agent type to delegate to
  input_format: string, optional
  output_format: string, optional

SEED:
  name: string, required, unique within skill
  description: string, required
  content: string, required, the knowledge itself
  domain: string, default same as skill domain
  tags: string[]
  dependencies: string[], other seed names
  author: string
  version: integer, default 1

TOOL:
  name: string, required
  description: string, required
  command: string, required
  type: 'cli' | 'mcp', default 'cli'
  config: object, optional, for MCP tools only

EXAMPLE:
  input: string, what user says
  output: string, what agent produces
  description: string, scenario label

REFERENCE:
  url: string, full URL
  title: string, document title
  description: string, what it provides
seeds.author: mongoBrain

seeds.name: skill-design-patterns
seeds.description: Best practices and anti-patterns for designing effective skills
seeds.content:
SKILL DESIGN PATTERNS

NAMING:
- kebab-case: 'code-review', 'api-documentation'
- Be specific: 'k8s-cluster-setup' not 'kubernetes'
- Avoid generic: 'helper', 'utils', 'misc'

TRIGGERS:
- 3-5 variations (synonyms, abbreviations, bilingual)
- Specific enough to avoid false matches
- Test: would this trigger ONLY match this skill?

PRIORITY CONVENTION:
  10 = briefing/planning and final save
  9  = core identity and methodology steps
  8  = implementation and execution
  7  = review, QA, validation
  6  = optional enrichment (examples, references)

GUIDELINES vs SEEDS:
- Guideline = 'what to DO' (procedure, numbered steps)
- Seed = 'what to KNOW' (reference material, patterns)
- If it changes between executions -> guideline
- If it's always the same knowledge -> seed

AGENT DELEGATION:
- Use 'agent' field only where specialization helps
- Common agents: researcher, coder, reviewer, designer
- Not every guideline needs an agent

TOOLS:
- Only real, runnable commands
- Use <placeholder> for variable parts
- 4 types: cli (shell), mcp (MCP server), api (HTTP), manual (user instruction)
- Default type is cli if omitted

DEPENDENCIES:
- depends_on = hard requirements (B can't run without A)
- Don't list soft references as dependencies

ANTI-PATTERNS:
- Skill with 1 guideline (too coarse, split into steps)
- Seed that's actually a procedure (move to guideline)
- Generic triggers that match everything
- Placeholder tools nobody will run
- prompt_base with step-by-step instructions (those go in guidelines)

2. Identity: name 'code-review', triggers ['review', 'code review', 'PR review']
3. Prompt base: 'You are a senior code reviewer. Follow the checklist...'

5. Seeds: review-checklist patterns, common code smells
6. Tools: git diff, gh pr view
